reviewText: The plot of the book has been simplified, the dialog is not particularly faithful to the book, and the overall tone is rather more melodramatic. However, there are few really glaring errors in terms of spoiling the period atmosphere, except for Rochester's statement that no one would care if he and Jane lived together without being married. In 1971 when the film was made, perhaps few people would have. In the Victorian era when the action takes place, every woman in their social circle would have refused to associate with any kept mistress or allow her to appear at respectable gatherings.The acting is good, and it's nice to see major characters who are not Hollywood stereotypically attractive.  The costumes are rather a mixed bag of mid-19th-century styles. The settings aren't bad. Thornfield Hall could be more luxurious, but Lowood School is done very well, complete with the constant noise of many girls chanting different lessons in the same room. The lighting is excellent, and the background music is sweeping enough to make you forgive a great deal.EXCEPT:The DVD quality is atrocious.  The many and large streaks and blips on the screen, always worst right in the middle of it, are constantly spoiling the film.  I don't care if they had to use an old print, there is editing software to clean up this kind of thing. I spent about every other screen being distracted by a huge green line all the way down the middle--they could at minimum have cleaned up major problems like that.So, when you buy this DVD you're getting your $4.99 worth.  No more.

reviewText: I was so excited to find this version of Jane Eyre with George C. Scott and Susannah York.  After reading JE in HS this was the first version of the film I saw, except for the Orson Welles-Joan Fontaine version.  I have been wistfully hoping to see this one again for 44 years.  Holy smokes -- that's a long time to wait.  The performances are understated and very fine.  I wish it could have been multipart so the characters could have had more scenes and dialogue to work with.  The film quality is very grainy and dark.  I don't think this has been digitally remastered, as one would expect a LOT more clarity, less muddy shadows, and so on.  It was just about this time that films were being filmed by only candlelight.  Seems to me Barry Lyndon was the first film using just candlelight to light a scene.  It was a big deal at the time.So here's my rating from best version of JE to my least favorite.  The Ciaran Hinds-Samantha Morton version is the best IMHO.  It is much more dramatic and less understated than this one.  Hinds runs the gamut of emotion from elation to desperation to total despair, to finally, relief and gratitude (and tears -- the man can cry copiously on cue.)  A great actor.  Samantha equalled his performance -- they were well-matched.  It was multipart if I recall, so more scenes could be included.  Then comes the Timothy Dalton version, which is also multipart, so the actors could play many more scenes which gave them time to more fully realize the book.  There was even some room for humor here and there, as when Rochester wants to give Jane money for her journey to see her sick aunt but she has no change.  Timothy is one of the best actors around.  Then comes this George C. Scott version, followed by the Michael Fassbender version.  Both well-acted with plenty of Gothic atmosphere.  Then the Orson Welles version -- a bit corny with the light focusing just on Welles' "pretty" eyes as if to suggest a slightly mad psyche, Fontaine's usual confused and wistful look (she too often depended upon this doubtful look to carry her performance along), and Welles' monotonic Ja--a-a-a-ane, Ja--a-a-a-ne!!  Still, not bad for the late '30's or early '40s, and a young Elizabeth Taylor as Helen Burns.  And finally, the William Hurt version.  I felt Hurt was miscast in the role -- he brought little to it; he seemed catatonic throughout.  His character should have possessed barely contained rage and despair, or even irony, at the fate destiny had brought upon him.  There is also a Tony Roberts version (is that his name?) which was average.

reviewText: Although this "digitally remastered" video is of poor quality, this rendition of Jane Eyre is still one of the best made. Susannah York is bit too pretty for Jane but she deftly captures the character and brings the melancholy Jane to life. George C. Scott perfectly plays the tortured Mr. Rochester.  None have eclipsed his stellar performance. Add a haunting John Williams score and you have a blend that works beautifully together. It is just sad that the movie was not better preseved as it is a classic.  Well-worth the time, however, in spite of the poor quality.

reviewText: Of all the actresses who have attempted this role, belated congratulations to Miss Susannah York for alone understanding "Jane" to the core, a knowledge absolutely necessary to render the character in a manner that Miss Bronte herself would assuredly recognize and approve.No other film actress has achieved Jane's self possession, self reliance, modesty, and self control in a way that consistently points to the novel itself, rather than some film director's misguided attempts to deliver a trivialized cartoon cut out. And it is these attributes that render Miss York's treatment of Jane's deeply held emotions all the more affecting, since they are kept under lock and key.In short, Miss York appears to have read the novel.Some other actresses have come somewhat close, (Joan Fontaine) while others have evidently had no conception of what on earth they were doing (Virginia Bruce).Suffice it to say that up to now, Susannah York has bested all others. As Mr. Roderick, George C. Scott is too old, but turns in a serviceable performance otherwise.Plaudits also to the cinematography for achieving a truly romantic bleakness comparable the paintings of Caspar David Friederich. Delbert Mann understood the importance of landscape to this story, (another key attribute jettisoned in other versions) and for this he is to be congratulated.Finally, the sumptuous and unforgettable score of John Williams. Forget hackneyed "Star Wars"--for this is a score of genuine musical achievement, richly romantic, stirring and melancholic all at the same time, not to mention being eminently listenable on its own terms.Three cheers to all concerned in this A-1 production.
summary: Susannah York easily the best Jane.

reviewText: I personally did not like (hated) this version of Jane Eyre for a few reasons.  First, the quality of the film, lighting, sound was poor to me.  It was hard to watch and really hard to hear. The sound of was out sync.  Second, the script did not make sense at some points.  I am not an Eyre purist, but If you have read the book even once, you will feel that the movie does not make sense.  There is no buildup to the romance.  There are no looks, connections or anything. He just declares his love but you don't know why or even how. He could have been saying it to the housekeeper!  Third, the leads are so distant and cold. I know that others have commented on the age difference.  Yeah, it is funny but it would not bother me if there were some on-screen connections.  Also, this Jane is pretty sassy and not at all like the servant she was to purported to be.  And, the scene where  Rochester is talking to Bertha was just bad....I don't know why screenwriters feel the need to change this story. It is so compelling on its face.  I can understand that we need to modernize the language but please keep the basic story in tact.
summary: Did not like this movie version

reviewText: It's hard to imagine a better gothic romance than "Jane Eyre" -- gloomy vast houses, mysterious secrets, and a brooding haunted man with a dark past. And while there have been lots of movie and TV adaptations, one of the absolute best is the 1970 TV movie starring Susannah York and George C Scott. "Jane Eyre" spends too long on Jane's school days (and not quite enough on the Thornfield days), but the two lead actors are absolutely brilliant in their roles.Jane Eyre was an orphan, abused and neglected at a boarding school run by a tyrannical, hypocritical minister. But Jane refuses to let anyone push her down -- and many years later, Jane moves on by applying to Thornfield Hall for a governess position. She soon becomes the teacher and friend to the sprightly French girl Adele. Then she encounters her employer, Mr. Rochester, a cynical, embittered man who spends little time at Thornfield.They are slowly drawn together into a powerful love, despite their different social stations -- and Rochester's apparent attentions to a shallow, snotty aristocrat. But strange things are happening at Thornfield -- injuries, fires, and a mysterious "danger." Jane and Rochester finally confess their feelings to each other, but their wedding is interrupted when Rochester's dark past comes to light.The biggest problem with the 1970 adaptation of "Jane Eyre" is that it spends too long at Jane's rotten school, and not quite enough time at Thornfield -- it could have benefited from another half an hour to flesh things out slightly, and include a few more important scenes that the TV movie didn't have (like the gypsy fortuneteller). So it's a credit to everything ELSE in this movie that it's still very good.Director Delbert Mann does an excellent job here, smoothly gliding through the three phases of Jane's life, slowly building up the gothic feel of the movie until Rochester's secret is revealed. And he weaves in some truly brilliant, intense scenes, such as when Rochester wakes to find Jane missing, and races around Thornfield searching for her, or when Jane joyously rejects the fanatical advances of the self-righteous St. John ("You cannot love just God alone!").But the best part is York and Scott, who have electric chemistry. York gives the role the passionate, rebellious undercurrent that you'd expect from Jane Eyre, and she's more striking than conventionally pretty. Scott seems a bit too gritty at first (breaking stuff?), but he soon turns on the passionate, embittered aspect of Rochester -- especially when the truth about Bertha comes out, and he sits sadly in her tower cell murmuring softly to the madwoman."Jane Eyre" is definitely one of the better adaptations of Bronte's classic gothic romance -- it's a bit too short, but the performances are absolutely awe-inspiring. Definitely worth seeing.
summary: The love people have for each other

reviewText: Delbert Mann's direction is somewhat pedestrian but the cast and visuals more than compensate his static approach. George C. Scott is wonderful as Rochester while Susannah York is capable and satisfactory in the title role (Jane Eyre) yet she seems to lack some passion either from an inward or outward perspective. Jack Hawkins is brilliant as the malevolent headmaster. However, the motivations for his hideous nature are left unexplored. This version of JANE EYRE is beautifully photographed and richly textured and very compelling. John William's score is very British and appropriately composed to augment the visuals. In all this is a well intentioned and splendid production but seems to lack some of the mysterious and enigmatic qualities of earlier versions. Yet it is still very enthralling.

reviewText: This TV production of 1970 starring Susannah York and George C. Scott is another proof of how difficult it is to adopt "Jane Eyre" to the screen, and how much can go wrong in doing so. It is true that the movie suffered in the transfer to DVD - some scenes which were complete in the original were shortened and so badly edited that there are striking continuity gaps and that even one crucial scene between Jane and Rochester starts in the middle of a sentence! But even if the editing were better, the film would not be. The script is bad, the portrayal of the characters is untrue to the novel and nearly all actors are miscast. As a consequence one does not have the feeling of watching an adaptation of Charlotte Bront's novel at all. The problem is not only that a number of scenes are shortened or left out - this is the case with all the short adaptations - but that the remaining scenes do no at all capture the tone, the spirit, the atmosphere and the concept of the novel.This Jane Eyre for example completely leaves out Gateshead and begins with Jane's arrival at Lowood. While this is perfectly all right, since some scenes must by necessity be left out, it is not understandable that, instead of using the time gained (so to speak) and thoroughly portraying Jane's friendship with Helen, the influence Helen has for Jane's development, the lecture in Christian stoicism that she teaches her, the film nearly exclusively concentrates on the physical ill-treatment of Helen, which is driven to absurd extremes in this adaptation. What Helen has to suffer is bad enough as described in the novel, but here Miss Scatchard is portrayed as a kind of sadistic prison ward, who deliberately wants to drive Helen to a premature death. And this is about all which happens at Lowood. If you compare that to the deep impact the years spent in Lowood have on Jane in the novel, one can only state with regret that the movie does not even touch the surface of that particular episode in Jane's life. And this is the problem throughout this adaptation: It rushes from scene to scene, very often without transition, and nowhere comes even near the essence of the novel.  The dialogues are an odd mixture of made-up lines and lines from the novel, very clumsily patched together, and the scenes between Jane and Rochester are so shortened that both share only 5 minutes together on screen before they fall in love, and the little conversation they have contains nothing of the brilliance, the intensity and also the humour of the conversations between Rochester and Jane in the novel. But the scriptwriter not only did Bront's language injustice but in addition managed to ruin her moral set-up with just one sentence. When Rochester and Jane go to see Rochester's wife after the would-be wedding, Rochester says: "Yet I once loved her [his wife] as I love you now." The whole moral concept of the novel depends on the fact that Rochester is indeed an innocent victim of an amoral scheme and was trapped into marrying a mad woman whom he never loved, and that his effort to seek a true life partner is, if not sanctified by God's and man's law, yet understandable and forgivable! But this one sentence completely undermines Bront's whole carefully constructed moral concept and turns Rochester into a dirty old man who wants a new young wife because his old one is of no use to him any longer.From the errors regarding the script to the errors regarding the casting: Now I am by no means one of those who insist on physical resemblance between an actor and the literary figure he portrays, but by no stretch of imagination is it possible to picture lovely, blonde, blue-eyed and full-mouthed Susannah York as the novel's plain heroine. In addition, Ms York was in her thirties when the film was shot and looks it. Played by her, the novel's shy, reserved and inexperienced young Jane becomes a perfectly poised, graceful and mature woman, completely sure of herself and her deserts. I do not say that Susannah York does not play well and convincingly but the woman she portrays is not Bront's Jane Eyre. To cast George C. Scott as Rochester must have been motivated by the desire to have a Rochester who looked old enough to make the 18 years difference in age between Jane and Rochester plausible. Scott looks as if he were around 50 but acts in various scenes as if he were 70.To compliment the "maturity" of the leading actors all passion, desire and despair seems to have been deliberately wrung out of the script. The scene between Jane and Rochester after the wedding, the emotional climax of the novel, has become a calm, rational conversation between two middle-aged persons, at the end of which Rochester falls asleep. When Jane returns to him in the last scene, he is just as mildly pleased as a grandfather who has just been paid a visit in his old people's home by his favourite granddaughter. The only character who displays an appropriate amount of emotion is St. John, of all people. Ian Bannen plays him so passionately and his eager plea for Jane's love is so touching that one gets the impression that Bannen was modelling his St. John on the Rochester of the novel. But good though Bannen is, his St. John is just as far from the novel as York's Jane and Scott's Rochester. The only redeeming features of this very disappointing "Jane Eyre" are the locations and the score, and I would only recommend this production to those who want to watch and compare every single adaptation of "Jane Eyre".
summary: Love in an old people's home

reviewText: As much as I am pleased I finally found George C. Scott's version of this novel/movie, I am so unhappy with the quality of editing and the horrendous film quality of this DVD!  I find it hard to believe someone released it as it is!  I saw the original version on TV years ago.  I have never been able to forget it!  The acting is first class, the music is to die for, (I have the LP for the sound track).  But, after years of searching for a DVD of this TV movie, I was horror struck at how dark the scenes were, and how poor the audio was.  It looks like someone has made multiple copies of it over and over so now you have little viewing quality left and then decided to sell it in this DVD form.  Luckily, Scott and York still give brilliant performances in spite of how the DVD was produced.  The movie's music theme still haunts me decades after first hearing it!

reviewText: Omnibus and Sagittarius presents Charlotte Bronte's  ~ "Jane Eyre" (1971) (UK) (108 min/Color) (Dolby digitally remastered) --- Director Delbert Mann gave us a fine adaptation of the Bronte novel to ever be put on film --- George C. Scott's Rochester is the best interpretations of the character from the author's description --- Susannah York was much to attractive and pretty for the role of Jane Eyre, but she is one of my favorite British actresses --- The music by John Williams was haunting with shades of other early works by Williams, such as his score for "Dracula" (1979) --- However, Susannah York and George C. Scott's scenes have the most chemistry and tenderness in them, still believe this version is one of the best out there --- Although this release for picture quality in places is dark and fading, with color changes in some of the early scenes --- Still the performances shine through and that's what I like about this VCI release..Special footnote -- Both cast members George C. Scott and Susannah York were Emmy nominated for their single performance in a leading television role (NBC) --- But the good news is John Williams in 1972 Won Emmy Outstanding Achievement in Music Composition - For a Special Program (NBC)Under the production staff of:Delbert Mann  [Director]Charlotte Bront  [novel "Jane Eyre"]Jack Pulman  [writer]Hugh Attwooll  [Associate Producer]Frederick H. Brogger [Producer]James Franciscus [Producer]John Williams  [Original Score]Paul Beeson  [Cinematographer]Peter Boita  [Film Editor]Alex Vetchinsky [Art Diirector]Anthony Mendleson  [Costume Design]BIOS:1.  Delbert Mann  [Director]Date of Birth:  30 January 1920 - Lawrence, KansasDate of Death:  11 November 2007 - Los Angeles, California2.  George C. ScottDate of Birth:  18 October 1927 - Wise, VirginiaDate of Death:  22 September 1999 - Westlake Village, California3.  Susannah York  (aka: Susannah Yolande Fletcher)Date of Birth:  9 January 1939 - Chelsea, London, England, UKDate of Death:  Still Living4.  John Williams  [Composer]Date of Birth:  8 February 1932 - Floral Park, Long Island, New YorkDate of Death:  Still Livingthe cast includes:George C. Scott ...  Edward RochesterSusannah York ...  Jane EyreIan Bannen ...  St. John RiversJack Hawkins ...  Mr. BrocklehurstNyree Dawn Porter ...  Blanche IngramRachel Kempson ...  Mrs. FairfaxSara Gibson ...  Jane Eyre as a ChildCheck out "The British Are Coming" is the three minute sum and pieces of various British Films coming attractions to view on VCI, other than that no other bonus or extras --- Must once again make mention of the musically of Jane Eyre - must rate this as one of John William's greatest creations --- The listener is immediately transported into an English countryside --- With various orchestral emotions of every scene is well conveyed. In the long term the soundtrack will probably be viewed as more valuable than the film since, like the novel itself, it transports you to another reality where you generate your own images while being stimulated by the richness of the material --- The music captures the atmosphere of the book which took this film into another realm of classic stories --- This is not a perfect film, but the direction and cast is the best thing to it for my four star rating.Total Time: 108 min on DVD ~ VCI Entertainment #8429 ~ (9/28/2010)
summary: "Jane Eyre (1971) ... George C. Scott ... VCI Ent. (2010)"

reviewText: I really like the recent BBC version of this story, but this adaption is still one of the better versions too.George C. Scott really captures the gruffness of Rochester.  And although most like their Rochester handsome, there is really no big indication in the book that he is that way.  Jane Eyre admits point blank that she doesn't find his looks attractive, I don't think she was lying.  Scott exudes outright power and that is more than a little attractive for any woman.I found the scene in which Scott's Rochester sings to Blanche in front of Jane the most heart rending out of all the versions.The fact that both leads were a bit older than their characters didn't bother me.As others have pointed out, the copy of the film is in poor state.  And unfortunately we will never have a properly restored copy.  According to fans on [...], the master print has been lost by the studio.  So the versions we are left with are just copies.

reviewText: Delbert Mann's Jane Eyre is a well-loved television classic. However it cannot be considered the definite version since the Masterpiece Theater version has the luxury of four hours to flesh out nearly every detail of the book. That being said, what this version lacks in duration it compensates by exploring certain dimensions that the mini-series tends to breeze over.Lowood Institution is especially well done. While other versions make it look like a nice place to live, Mann gives it a distinct Dickensian flavor. Miss Scatcherd reprimands Helen Burns for almost everything. She even makes her stand outside in the rain for getting up without asking permission. Jane hears Helen coughing outside and her face becomes hardened at the injustice of it all--it's an unforgettable expression.I was also impressed with Ian Bannen's portrayal of St. John Rivers. He plays the character with a certain zeal and pharasitical air. He wants to serve God in a large way but doesn't realize that a parish in England is just as important as a mission field in India. His "Come with me...I claim you" sermon where he makes eye contact with Jane in the pulpit" is one of the film's finest moments. I've seen other versions that write St. John Rivers a dull, bland, incedental character to give the viewer the impression: "Yuck. I hate St. John. He just ain't crap compared to Mr. Rochester." I think Charlotte Bronte wrote Jane's two suitors with equally fascinating personalities so I felt refreshed to see both the pros and cons of each character in this movie.The biggest problem with this version is that it begins at Lowood while Mrs. Reed is referred to rather than shown; it could have benefitted from fifteen minutes before Jane's life at school to help the audience understand her significance. Nevertheless, this is a good solid representation of Charlotte Bronte's novel that captures the bleak atmosphere of a gothic romance and features a nearly impeccable cast.Susannah York is a little too pretty to play Jane (red hair and blue eyes?) but she nails the character to a T. She displays courage, intelligence, wit, charm and integrity underneath her quiet, reserved personality and you don't wonder why Mr. Rochester preferred her over Blanche Ingram. George C. Scott stars off a little too gruff as Mr. Rochester but he eventually brings out the passionate, embittered aspects of the character. Barbara Young and Jack Hawkins are outstandingly villanous as Miss Scatcherd and Mr. Brocklehurst, Rachel Kempson is perhaps the definite screen version of Mrs. Fairfax--a symbol of British gentility, Nyree Dawn Porter a deliciously flighty and snotty Blanche and Jean Marsh brilliant in her cameo as the very off-centered Bertha.Costumes and sets are excellent, cienematography contains rich and dark colors like an oil painting and John Williams presents one of the most beautiful period pieces ever set to film.Not the best Jane Eyre but still a very darn good one!
summary: Too short to do the book justice but marked with great performances and music.

reviewText: This version was originally aired in theaters in the UK, but only on television here in the US. Although the DVD claims to be "digitally remastered," the quality is still, quite frankly, terrible. Apparently the story goes that the original film was lost somewhere along the line, so the video releases use the TV version. That is apparent with bad, cuts and jumps in scenes that pop up occasionally throughout the movie, most likely at points where there were commercial breaks. After the fire in Rochester's room, Jane asks him if Grace Poole started the fire. One problem with that- there was no mention of the name "Grace Poole" at any time in the movie before this! That must have been a scene to have gotten cut, or the writers are morons. Take your pick.The picture isn't good, and despite boasting a score by John Williams, the sound isn't either.Despite being only an  hour and a half, the film starts with a length opening credits scene before young Jane arrives at Lowood. What the purpose of that was, I'm still not sure!Susannah York as Jane was gorgeous and at nearly 20 years too old, but her performance was pretty good. I liked that George C. Scott's Rochester was not very good-looking, but the lines about him not being handsome were cut for some reason! So disappointing. I thought Ian Bannen was too passionate as St. John and not enough the cold, unfeeling character of the book.Overall, this version was actually pretty decent. I couldn't find many negative things to say about it, really, which is a good thing. . Despite being too old, the cast did a pretty good job overall. Ultimately it suffered from time constraints. Other than the horrible picture and audio quality of the DVD, it's really not bad It's a shame that the original film was supposedly lost! Maybe it will somehow be miraculously found one day?

reviewText: I liked this story so well when I first saw it, I wrote a musical to it which was performed for 5 nights at the St. Timothy Theater in Baltimore.  I couldn't have done it without having first seeing this film which followed the book so carefully.  Thanks for putting it on DVD!  I will enjoy going back in time and seeing it again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've seen a lot of versions of Jane Eyre and loved most of them, though some rank higher than others on my list of all time favorite movies based on Charlotte Bronte's amazing book.  The George C. Scott version is way at the top not only because I like his acting, but because Miss Bronte was so specific in her descriptions of Rochester, the hero of the story.  He was not a handsome man.  He'd lived his life resenting those who'd tricked him into his first marriage and was a hardened individual.  In addition, he was bossy, grumpy, and sarcastic.  Mr. Scott is the perfect arrogant hero, and his chemistry with Ms York is the icing on their perfect gothic romance.
summary: One of the best versions out there

reviewText: Please give us a break, all you people who review and rate movies based on some book you read. This is a movie, it is not a book, so don't expect it to be exactly the same as a story you read before. And especially, don't expect the actors and actresses to look the way you imagined them to look when you read about the characters in a book. How silly! Aside from the fact that no two people will imagine the same character looking the same after reading the same book, even more important is the fact that if the selection of an actor were done based on the physical description in a book, we would never get the pleasure of experiencing the talents of the really great actors.So, this is a wake up call to all MOVIE reviewers: No movie review is valid if it tries to compare the movie with a book by the same name. Also, PLEASE include the UPC Code of the movie you are reviewing if you are discussing the quality of the DVD production. Amazon just mixes them all together, so nobody can tell which are good and which are poor quality productions unless you include the UPC in your review.All ranting aside, I love this movie. I would pay any price for a top quality, complete DVD release of it. If you find one, please share the UPC code with the rest of us. Thanks.
summary: It's a MOVIE not a BOOK

Title: N/A

reviewText: I was excited to find this "Jane Eyre," as I had fond memories of this 1971 version being my first encounter with the Jane Eyre story.  What story?  It's abbreviated to the point of being nearly unrecognizable.  (Read the book first.  I've yet to see ANY production translate some of the beautiful moments in the text to the screen.)  This is either a DVD of a very bad print -- with cuts so huge one wonders if parts of the film were lost and some genius decided to sell it "as is" -- or simply a terrible television adaptation.  This is surprising because the credits of those involved are estimable: Jack Pulman (who adapted "I Claudius" for the television!) did the teleplay; John Williams wrote the score (and revamped it into the score for "Dracula" some 8 years later); George C. Scott plays Rochester (good casting) and Suzanna York, as good an actress as she may be, is completely miscast in the role.  Not only is she too "mature," but far too pretty.  Don't waste your time or energy on this.  What a disappointment.

Title: N/A

reviewText: If this movie has been digitally re-mastered as is claimed then we are all in trouble. I allowed four minutes viewing time before shutting it down.Music and sound effects drown out the dialog, joined with harsh scratches in the images, skips and jumps in the dialogue and washed out color. The music seems to have been recorded on one of those old fashion stenography machines used in the nineteen fifties. The left hand portion of a sign, giving the name of the institution the actress is entering during the opening scene is completely blacked out, obscuring the first two letters on the left hand side of the institution's sign. Say goodbye to any foreshadowing the sign was to introduce.Dated cultural hick cupping aside, the technical work, or so-called remastering,is so poor that it constantly interrupts a viewer from enjoying any positive aspects of the feature. I don't know if this is a good classical movie or not as both visuals and sound are so bad that one can't make a fair judgment as to the movie's content.Scott and York would be unhappy with this if they saw this and probably would not allow it to be shown in its current condition.  The original cut has to be better then this so called re-mastered copy.I don't expect perfection in older movies and can overlook a lot, including dated movie techniques. To claim that this feature has been re-masterd is simply not true. The technical work is so bad, that it makes it impossible to view the feature as it was originally intended.
summary: Poor Quality Control, Washed out Color, Sound, Scratches

reviewText: I read Jane Eyre (who didn't) in school years ago.  In the meantime I've seen versions with Rochester played by handsome actors and Jane by beautiful actresses and it is SO not the real story.  One version even changed the story and made St.John and Jane RICH cousins at the end!  Charlotte Bronte must have turned in her grave!THIS version is so heart-rending; George C Scott though not handsome is as always, a powerful force on the screen and Susanna York is the perfect Jane.  You get to see how she was shaped by events before Thornfield and then there's just the right amount of "eeriness to the castle.  My only criticism is that the original film must have been very deteriorated before they digitized it, and in spots the quality of the picture is affected; but in the end it doesn't matter as the performances are SO superior to others I've watched.
summary: Best version of this story ever

reviewText: Not the best version of the novel but certainly one of the best.  Scott and York are superb and the music is easily one of the most beautiful and memorable made for any TV film.  Scott brings an appropriate sense of danger and anger to the role while York makes Jane into a strong, thoughtful, intelligent woman instead of a mousy, passive servant.  I highly recommend this version, especially to those whose imaginations are broader and deeper than those who can't handle production values that are not state-of-the-art.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I am a big fan of the novel JANE EYRE and have been since I discovered it in the sixth grade.  I remember watching this film version with George C. Scott and Susannah York on TV when I was a kid and liking it and I was delighted to get a chance to view it again as an adult.Susannah York in this version is both too old and too beautiful to be Jane as described in the novel but her portrayal convincingly creates  the kind of woman with whom a man like Rochester could fall totally in love.  And George C. Scott really does make a great Rochester.  Aside from Scott's  great acting chops his looks and age are much more in line with the Rochester of the book then say Timothy Dalton or Toby Stephens.  Actually I still like the Jane Eyre mini-series with Dalton the best but this is a very decent attempt at capturing the beloved story on film.
summary: George C. Scott Makes A Good Rochester
